thread.title: Hills Junior Sports Star winners
thread.title_full: Hills Junior Sports Star winners | News Local

author: David Catt
title: Hills Junior Sports Star winners

organizations.name: hills shire times 2016 young sporting spirit
hills shire times young sporting spirit award

text:
Kira Ward won the Hills Shire Times Junior Sport Star Award at the presention evening at Waterview in Bicentennial Park, Homebush. Hills Shire Kira Ward, Olivia Lawne and Hills Little League big winners at Junior Sports Star awards David Catt, 23, 2017 12:25pm Australian footballer Ellie Carpenter wins NewsLocal’s Sports Star medal
GYMNAST Kira Ward has beaten a strong field to be crowned the Hills Shire Times 2016 Junior Sports Star winner at a gala dinner at the Waterview function centre at Sydney Olympic Park on Wednesday night.
Kira, who turned 17 earlier this year, is a six-time Australian national gymnastics champion and a double mini trampoline world champion.
media_camera Kira Ward in training.
The Kellyville gymnast was selected to the Gymnastic Australia national trampoline senior squad and competes at level 10, the highest possible level.
Ward has had an impressive run of results, including being named the Double Mini Trampoline World Champion for U17 girls at the Trampoline Gymnastics World Age Championships in Denmark in December 2015.
“I love going up in the air and doing flips, and then doing it again. It’s different from any thing else you do,” she said.
In 2017, she’s eyeing off the double mini trampoline title at the World Games, followed by a return to the world champions and hopefully a place on the Olympics teams in 2020 and 2024.
Ward also dedicates what little spare time she has to training up the next generation of gymnastics champions at C2k Fitness and Aquatic Centre Castle Hill, saying her average day consists of “school, training, coaching, dinner and bed”.
“It’s great giving back to them and seeing them develop their skills and goals,” she said.
The other three finalists in the category were Capri Vidler (all rounder), Jayde Oakley (gymnastics) and Liam Christie (trampoline).
The Junior Sports Star awards are proudly sponsored by Rebel.
media_camera Olivia Lawne won the Hills Shire Times Young Sporting Spirit Award.
Olivia Lawne, of Northmead, lives and breathes rugby league, playing and refereeing five times per week.
She referees for both the Parramatta district referees and the Catholic rugby league competition and plays for the Hills Bulls all-girls team.
media_camera Olivia Lawne in her referee uniform.
Her dedication to her sport far beyond just her playing team saw her named the Hills Shire Times 2016 Young Sporting Spirit winner.
Olivia, who also plays AFL, touch football and OzTag, said her passion to be involved in rugby league after she outgrew the mixed competitions saw her pick up the refereees whistle.
“I started at nine playing with the boys, but when I could no longer play I started refereeing,” she said.
“I love being out there on the park and teaching the kids to play safe.
“(Being a full-time referee) is one of ony dreams and it would make me really proud of myself if I could do that.”
She said the greatest challenge she faces on the field is not from the players but from overzealous parents.
“Sometimes I have felt like giving up, when I cop it from the sidelines, but my parents have always pushed me to not give up,” she said.
The finalists in the Young Sporting Spirit category included Kyra Wheatley (skiing), Lachlan Compton (football) and Hunter Hosking (rugby union).
The Young Sporting Spirit award was sponsored by Simonds Homes.
media_camera The Hills Little League under-12 team at the Little League Australia Championships in 2016.
The Hills Little League under 12s team beat out 17 other strong contenders from across Sydney and the Central Coast to be crowned the 2016 Team Spirit winners.
media_camera Executive officer Louise Riddell and assistant coach Scott Wright accept the Team Spirit Award on behalf of the Hills Little League U12 Team.
The representative squad, made up of under-12s players from Quakers Hill, Rouse Hill, Castle Hill and Winston Hills, was selected to play in the Little League World Series in Williamsport, Pennsylvania, last year, after being crowned champions at the Australian Little League championships.
There they beat sides representing Europe and Africa. They finished in the top 8 in the world.
Receiving the award, assistant coach Scott Wright said: “This is an awesome thing four our club, considering baseball isn’t as big as other sports here tonight.”
He said the trip to Williamsport was an amazing experience for the team and their coaching staff, and was a huge result for Australia baseball as they were only the fourth team ever from Australia to make it to the World Series.
The Team Spirit category is proudly sponsored by SportsTG.
